Selection of the members of the
'Varsity tennis team will be made
this week. The team is to be composed of four members who will
play both singles and doubles.
Captain Belt has arranged a
good schedule with five trips away
from Baltimore. This year, when
the team plays at home, it will be
able to use the new grass courts
at Homewood.. The schedule is:
April 24—Gettysburg College at
Gettysburg.
April 27—Virginia Military Institute at Homewood.
May I—St. John's College at
Homewood.
May 8—Georgetown University
at Washington.
May 15—University of Pennsylvania at Philadelphia.
May 22—Haverford College at
Haverford.
Catholic University at Washington—date undecided.
Trials for the team will be held
at Homewood this week if Mr.
Chalk ever gets the courts ready.
Anyone who has not yet spoken to
Captain Belt and desires to try for
a place on the team will please do
so at once.
The Tennis Team.

The tennis team at Hopkins is
a new departure of the last couple
of years. Two important matches
were played last year—with Western Maryland College and with
Navy. Western Maryland succumbed, but the Annapolis boys
were a little too strong.
Clary, Du Bray, Springer, Belt,
and Post made up the team last
season; this year there will be
much greater competition, and several new men will probably get
places. Among those out art Hamilton, Springer, Rice, Bacon, Du
Bray, Brune. Rosenfeld, Corner,
Belt.

At Homewood on Saturday the
rain, which had made it impossible
for the baseball game with Harvard earlier in the afternoon,
stopped just before the game began, and left the field, despite its
excellent drainage system, • muddy
and covered in places with puddles
of water. The condition of the
grounds made the playing ludicrous
at times, when two men came together in body-checking or when
one tried to dodge the other. Falls
in the mud and water amused
the small crowd of spectators at
every point of the game.
The closeness of the score is due
to Harvard's brace in the second
half. In the first half Hopkins
showed good teamwork, and played
most of the time in the Crimson
territory. At the end of the half
the score stood 3-1 in Hopkins'
favor. Harvard scored first, after
four and a half minutes' play, when
Foristall passed to Blackett, who
shot the goal. During the next
four minutes Hopkins got to their
feet and scored three times. Paulus
secured the ball in Hopkins' territory, passed to Gail, Gail to Easter,
who scored the first Hopkins tally.
In thirty seconds Gail shot the
second goal, after a relay from
Everton. Within three more minutes Gail scored a second time, after
some clever dodging by Paulus,
who passed him the ball.
At this point Harvard braced up
and prevented further scoring. In
the second half, however, three
goals were credited to the visitors,
and only two to Hopkins. Harvard's defence tightened and her
attack played a more concerted
game. Her inaccuracy in shooting
for the net cost a number of goals
which, perhaps, would have won
the game for the Crimson. Sutton, the 'varsity goal, saved many
a try at goal in this period. Hopkins got the first score in the second half. Benedict, third attack,
did what seemed like a foolish bit
of playing when he ran up to the
net from his position, • but saved
his reputation by shooting the goal.
Harvard scored next, and in three
minutes Hopkins scored her last
point by a clever shot by Easter,
who received the ball from Gail.
Foristall and Gustafson passed to
Abbe for Harvard's third count,
and Gustafson shot the final goal
a second before the whistle blew.

It also transpired with the announcement of the President, that
he had wished to take this action
for a year or more previously, but
had been dissuaded from doing so
until the campaign for the Homewood funds and the technology appropriation were carried through.
During that time rumors of such
an intention had leaked into the
press, but always drew vigorous
denials.
"I have made so many statements about the affair," said President Remsen, when asked for a
word to the students through the
medium of THE NEWS-LETTER,
"that I can scarcely discuss it any
more.
"I cannot leave my present position, however, without a word to
the students of the University. I
want to thank them for their hearty
co-operation in all that tends to
make the better life of the University. My relations with them have
never been as close as I should like,
but I have been well informed in
regard to their work, and it has
been a great satisfaction to me to
know that, with very few exceptions, they have been earnest and
honest workers. I want to thank
them for their uniformly good behavior. We are fortunate in not
having students' troubles. In fact,
within my period of service, now
nearly thirty-six years, the number
of cases that have caused difficulty
to the administration has been
practically negligible. That means
more than I can, here express, but
I want the students to know that
I appreciate their attitude towards
the University. I am sure that no
one can live in this atmosphere,
partly created by the students,
without being distinctly benefited
by it. One consolation I have in
retiring from the presidency is that
in all probability I shall be .able to
come into • closer relations with the
students. I am not saying good-by
to anyone. I am expecting to be
in harness for a good while to
come, though just what my duties
will be I cannot now say."
It is understood that Dr. Remsen
will retain his chair as the B. N.
Baker Professor of Chemistry, and
that his resignation, if accepted by
the trustees, will give him opportunity for a more active part in the
chemical work than his duties as
president left time for.
The question of the next occupant of the president's chair has
naturally occasioned much discussion, but while many names have
been mentioned the possible action
of the trustees cannot be predicted.
Perhaps the names.most often considered are those of Woodrow Wilson and Dr. J. M. T. Finney, although various local celebrities
have been debated by the trustees
of the Trophy Room and the executive committee of the barber
shop. The general opinion seems
to be that some educator from a
distance will probably be the choice
for the place.

President Remsen's Resignation.

THE-NEws-LETTER wishes to express its deep regret at the resignation of President Remsen. For
eleven years he has directed the
destinies of the University—a period marked by steady growth,
constant progress, and wise preparation for the expansion yet to
come. During that time two great
endowment funds have been raised.
During that time the Homewood
idea has been conceived and safely
brought to the very eve of realization. And now the leader who has
guided us through these years of
toil and unrewarded hope, halts
upon the borders of the promised
land and resigns his trust to other
hands. President Remsen's selfsacrifice is worthy of the highest
admiration. To another will belong the honor of installing the University at Homewood; to another
will belong the glory of presiding
over it in the years of prosperity,
when fitly housed and fitly equipped
it will take its place at the head
of the universities •of America; but
let us not forget that these things
would never have been possible but
for the quiet effort and provident
sagacity of the man who is now
laying down his leadership.

The New Athletic Policies.

It will be remembered that in
the last issue of THE NEWS-LETTER
we devoted a good deal of space
and attention to the new athletic
policies and our views on the subject. It is not necessary to rehash

we have heard so many students
say that they fully approve of our
objections, and even that we did
not state them half strongly enough,
that we are going to take the
matter up again. In our letter
column we publish a very few of
the many letters we have received
on the subject. They certainly indicate that a large part of the student body is back of us in our contention that the policies are ab-

surd and unconstitutional, and that
the director of the gymnasium and
graduate manager have usurped
power that was not conferred oil
the director when the trustees appointed him or on the graduate
manager by the students. We,
therefore, call on the Athletic
Board to hold a mass-meeting and
submit each article of the policy
to a referendum of the students.
We invite letters on the subject
from all our subscribers.

Dr. James Schouler Gives Lectures on
President Johnson.
In March, 1908, Dr. James
Schouler, LL. D., of Boston, who
had lectured at the Hopkins • annually since 1891, founded a permanent lectureship in the University,
to be known as "The James Schouler Lectureship in History and Political Science." The donor expressed the wish that "such lectures
be given annually, if possible . . •
and that persons of promise or
Prominence be selected to lecture,
who are capable of interesting, as
Well as instructing, an audience."
The lectureship was inaugurated
Ifl 1909, and three courses have been
given by Abbott Lawrence Lowell;
George \V. Prothero of London,
editor of the Quarterly Review;
and John B. Moore. This year
the donor himself will deliver the
lectures. In six lectures on "President Johnson and Posterity," he
will present the results of extensive
investigations, which have not yet
been published.
The topics are as follows:
Monday, April 15 —"President
and Cabinet."
Wednesday, April 17 — "President Johnson's Southern Policy."
Friday, April 19—"The Policy
of Congress."
Monday, April 22—"Appeal to
the People."
Wednesday,April 24—"Congress
Dominant."
Friday, April 26 — "The Impeachment Failure."
The lectures are to be ,open to
the public and no cards of admission will be required. The lectures
Will be delivered in the Donovan
Room.

The Technical School.

The technical school is a reality.
Lnder the terms of the bill passed
at the recent session of the Maryland Legislature and signed a few
days ago by Governor Goldsborough, the University will receive
$600,000 from the State for the
construction of buildings and the
purchase of equipment and $50,000
annually for the maintenance of the
school. The money will be raised
by a bond issue.
The bill further provides that
in the new school there shall be
129 free scholarships, apportioned
to residents of Baltimore city and
the various counties in accordance
with their respective representation
in the House of Delegates; there
shall be six scholarships at large,
and three allotted to each of the
following colleges: Loyola, Maryland Agricultural, Mt. St. Mary's,
Rock Hill, St. John's, Washington, and Western Maryland. The
scholarships from these colleges
shall be given to applicant having
the best scholastic standing, regardless of their financial circumstances; the holders of the other
scholarships must be deserving
young men who could not get a
technical education unless free tuition were given them.
Of the 129 free scholarships, 27
will carry with them an additional
$200 which is intended to help out
poor boys who could not come
even if they had a scholarship. One
will go to each State Senatorial
district.
It is, of course, most fortunate
that the University obtained the
State appropriation for the technical school; however., it will prove
to be more fortunate still that the
appropriation comes just at this
time, if the Foster Bill, now before
Congress, is passed.
The Foster Bill calls for the avpropriation of $25,000 annually for
the maintenance of mining engineering courses in some institution
in each State, the amount to be
$5,000 the first year, with an increase of $5,000 each year until the
full $25,000 annually is reached.
If this bill passes—and the great
mining and transportation interests
of the country are behind it—the
mining work of the technological
school would be splendidly provided for. With the well-organized
geological department we now have
and the Maryland Geological Survey run in connection with it, we
could organize courses in mining
second to none in the country.

President Remsen's Resignation.

THE-NEws-LETTER wishes to express its deep regret at the resignation of President Remsen. For
eleven years he has directed the
destinies of the University—a period marked by steady growth,
constant progress, and wise preparation for the expansion yet to
come. During that time two great
endowment funds have been raised.
During that time the Homewood
idea has been conceived and safely
brought to the very eve of realization. And now the leader who has
guided us through these years of
toil and unrewarded hope, halts
upon the borders of the promised
land and resigns his trust to other
hands. President Remsen's selfsacrifice is worthy of the highest
admiration. To another will belong the honor of installing the University at Homewood; to another
will belong the glory of presiding
over it in the years of prosperity,
when fitly housed and fitly equipped
it will take its place at the head
of the universities •of America; but
let us not forget that these things
would never have been possible but
for the quiet effort and provident
sagacity of the man who is now
laying down his leadership.

and that persons of promise or
Prominence be selected to lecture,
who are capable of interesting, as
Well as instructing, an audience."
The lectureship was inaugurated
Ifl 1909, and three courses have been
given by Abbott Lawrence Lowell;
George \V. Prothero of London,
editor of the Quarterly Review;
and John B. Moore. This year
the donor himself will deliver the
lectures. In six lectures on "President Johnson and Posterity," he
will present the results of extensive
investigations, which have not yet
been published.

Monday, April 15 —"President
and Cabinet."
Wednesday, April 17 — "President Johnson's Southern Policy."
Friday, April 19—"The Policy
of Congress."
Monday, April 22—"Appeal to
the People."
Wednesday,April 24—"Congress
Dominant."
Friday, April 26 — "The Impeachment Failure."
The lectures are to be ,open to
the public and no cards of admission will be required. The lectures

The Technical School.

The technical school is a reality.
Lnder the terms of the bill passed
at the recent session of the Maryland Legislature and signed a few
days ago by Governor Goldsborough, the University will receive
$600,000 from the State for the
construction of buildings and the
purchase of equipment and $50,000
annually for the maintenance of the
school. The money will be raised
by a bond issue.
The bill further provides that
in the new school there shall be
129 free scholarships, apportioned
to residents of Baltimore city and
the various counties in accordance
with their respective representation
in the House of Delegates; there
shall be six scholarships at large,
and three allotted to each of the
following colleges: Loyola, Maryland Agricultural, Mt. St. Mary's,
Rock Hill, St. John's, Washington, and Western Maryland. The
scholarships from these colleges
shall be given to applicant having
the best scholastic standing, regardless of their financial circumstances; the holders of the other
scholarships must be deserving
young men who could not get a
technical education unless free tuition were given them.
Of the 129 free scholarships, 27
will carry with them an additional
$200 which is intended to help out
poor boys who could not come
even if they had a scholarship. One
will go to each State Senatorial
district.
It is, of course, most fortunate
that the University obtained the
State appropriation for the technical school; however., it will prove
to be more fortunate still that the
appropriation comes just at this
time, if the Foster Bill, now before
Congress, is passed.
The Foster Bill calls for the avpropriation of $25,000 annually for
the maintenance of mining engineering courses in some institution
in each State, the amount to be
$5,000 the first year, with an increase of $5,000 each year until the
full $25,000 annually is reached.
If this bill passes—and the great
mining and transportation interests
of the country are behind it—the
mining work of the technological
school would be splendidly provided for. With the well-organized
geological department we now have
and the Maryland Geological Survey run in connection with it, we
could organize courses in mining
second to none in the country.
